EDIT: and I just went through that Twitter thread: the issue is that PLAYERS couldn't reproduce the bug either. I **_CAN_** reproduce the bug. 100% of the time. The bug in that Twitter thread also didn't technically need to be fixed the way they fixed it. If they couldn't actually find out what was killing companions, they **_COULD_** have just modified their code so that companions can't die, even on the ship. The "climbing nothing" bug would have persisted (and maybe never been found), but the "companion dying and making my quest fail" bug would have been solved.

You might be able to 100% reproduce it, but if no one else can reproduce it then it means the impact is low and it won't be prioritized to be fixed as much compared to other bugs that have a bigger impact.

Other people **_CAN_** reproduce it. Just not the one guy at Riot who tried. Also has existed literally just as long as hail of blades has existed, and has probably ruined many thousands of games for many thousands of people (even if they didn't notice that a bug made them die).

The sad thing is that the game is **_SUPPOSEDLY_** played server-side, and yet my PC hardware/software and/or network setup is causing a bug that makes me unable to reliably activate a rune.... lmao.

I believe you. I also agree with your assessment that one option of the twitter post (wow that link image tho) is to just make it so companions can't die on the ship.

That being said, I think there are multiple facets here that are worth considering.

First, the "just make them unkillable on the ship" thing. This is factual. From the outside, it's reasonable. It embodies the "just this once" mindset, and it's a regular practice in the software industry. At my job, we do it via "feature flags" (lolol "feature"). When there's something new or unstable we're trying, we'll block off that code and wrap it in a "checkbox" we control, so we can turn on or off the feature/bug as needed. Unfortunately, there's are two primary tradeoffs with doing so, and one implied problem with this approach:

1. Code gets messy because we have to have two "working" paths of execution in addition to the logic that controls the flag as on/off.
2. Many times the feature itself is strictly working vs. not working, not new vs. old. In other words, if the core functionality has a problem, the only two options are (in this case) have a bug in HoB that triggers rarely (but severely impacts gameplay) vs. completely disabling HoB.

The implied problem is that failing to identify the root cause of the problem leads to potentially more problems. Imagine in the ladder example there were more cut-scenes where the NPC could climb ladders and die. Blocking off death from this particular ship wouldn't solve other ship cut-scenes from NPC death. We could add a second "don't die here" execution path, sure, but imagine if this was a game engine problem and not a game-specific problem. Maybe the issue wasn't limited to cut-scenes at all, and random death could happen under weird conditions everywhere. 

It boils down to, reproducing a bug is one thing, but despite how easy a bug is to reproduce, tracking down the **why** can be super tricky.

1) The bug may have been found faster, not requiring the workaround.
2) The bug eventually would have been found **_despite_** the workaround, and then later fixed properly. But the workaround would have temporarily improved the player experience while all this was happening.

There was a bug awhile ago, where snowball in ARAM was buggy. It got reported, and the thread outright mentioned _Snowball in ARAM_. Even with evidence, the Rioter who answered it said something along the lines of, "i couldn't replicate it, you sure it's a bug?" when he tried to recreate it.... in Summoners Rift. It took people telling him he was testing it on the wrong map for it to get figured out.

There's a difference between "i can't replicate it, can you tell me the steps you did that made it?" and "i couldn't replicate it, i don't think it's a bug." One is asking for more info that might not have been grabbed, one is just not caring.
